title: Whistle and Bells with Coral

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of silver and coral.

description: This small toy was most likely given to its owner as a christening present. Coral was thought to have excellent protective powers against illness, and the coral stick was a perfect remedy for a teething child. In period portraits depicting children, a whistle and bells sometimes hang from a chain around the child’s waist. This toy may have been made for Jonathan Fayerweather, who was born in Boston in 1722.
inscriptions:
Engraved on mount under whistle: IF
Engraved on mount under whistle: Fayerweather crest of a beaver with a fish in its mouth
Maker's mark on mount near juncture with coral, in rectangle: TE
credit_line: Purchased with funds provided by the Antiquarian Society through Mrs. J. Odgen Armour
publication_history: The Antiquarian Society (Art Institute of Chicago, 1951), no. 56 (ill.). M.G. Fales, Early American Silver for the Cautious Collector, (New York, 1970), no. 102 (ill.). Michael Clayton, "The Collector's Dictionary of the Silver and Gold of Great Britain and North America," (World Publishing Company, 1971) no. 424. Martha Gandy Fales, "Early American Silver," (New York: E.P. Dutton, 1973) no. 102 (ill.). Anita Gold, "Rattles once a Plaything of Cutthroats and Kings," Chicago Tribune, July 21, 1974, p. 8. Abby Hansen "Coral in Children's Portraits: A Charm Against the Evil Eye" Antiques 120 (1981) 1424–1431. Patricia E. Kane et al., Colonial Massachusetts Silversmiths and Jewelers (New Haven: Yale University Art Gallery, 1998) p. 465. Judith A. Barter, Elizabeth McGoey, et al., American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2016), cat. 13 (ill.). Elizabeth McGoey, ed., American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2018), https://publications.artic.edu/americansilver/reader/collection/section/6, cat. 13 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, Paul Revere's Boston: 1735–1818, Apr. 18–Oct. 12, 1975, cat. 109.

Art Institute, The Antiquarian Society of the Art Institute of Chicago, the First One Hundred Years, Apr. 23–June 19, 1977, cat. 174 (ill.).
provenance_text: Jonathan Fayerweather (1722–1755), Boston. With George C. Gebelein, Boston, by 1943; sold to Mrs. J. Ogden Armour, Chicago, 1943; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1943.
section_titles: Cat. 13  Whistle and Bells with Coral, c. 1722–23
